description:
Amaricoccus tamworthensis is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Amaricoccus. It is a Gram-negative, aerobic, and non-spore-forming coccus-shaped bacterium.

The species was first isolated from a soil sample collected near Tamworth, New South Wales, Australia, hence the specific epithet "tamworthensis." Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequence comparisons has shown that Amaricoccus tamworthensis is closely related to other members of the genus Amaricoccus, which are typically found in soil and aquatic environments.

Amaricoccus tamworthensis is known to grow optimally at moderate temperatures and neutral pH conditions. It is capable of utilizing a variety of organic carbon sources for energy and growth. The cells of this species typically occur singly or in pairs, and they do not form any distinctive colonial morphologies on agar media.

Further research is needed to fully understand the ecological roles and potential applications of Amaricoccus tamworthensis in various environmental and biotechnological contexts.
